column4: is the system using pulse-audio? maybe you need to restart the pa session server?
I have no idea, how can I check?
ps -ef | grep pulse - you should see two pulse processes
I think so.  Ubuntu 8.04 LTS (with the Mythbuntu packages as well)
no such file or directory as /usr/bin/pulseaudio.  And I'll point out that sound used to work, so it's not a case of something being terribly screwed up from the start
okay. I thought it might have crashed without you knowing. That would restart it. I thought Hardy had pulseaudio as default though
Anyway, if I suspect one application is hogging ALSA, how do I stop it?
hogging alsa? what do you mean?
I remember an old issue (and saw reference to it on a help page for what I'm looking at) that this issue seems eerily familiar to one where something is hogging alsa
You mean where the dmixer back-end isn't in use and one application has exclusive use of the sound device?
I remember gaim used to cause a similar issue
Anyway, do you think that could be the problem (seems similar, since non-amarok programs just silently don't play audio) and how would it get fixed?
Anyway, do you think that could be the problem (seems similar, since non-amarok programs just silently don't play audio) and how would it get fixed?
I don't know, sound applications are generally well-behaved around me  :)
alsa reload didn't do it, but alsa force-reload killed the processes holding onto alsa
